content:
This is the website for psych 5067 quantitative methods II. Everything that you need for the class should be included in this website, sans attending the lectures. Changes to syllabus, updates, and timely links will be shared on this landing page. Please check this home page weekly.
There are also links to the lecture slides, syllabus, homeworks, and readings. Links will be provided for any datasets that will be used for homework.

title: Welcome!

content:
Homework protocol Each will be turned in via email to a box.com address specific to the take home. For each you will need to attach to the email 1) an rmd or a rnw file of your code and answers and 2) a pdf of said file. Use your last name to label the files (e.g,. “Jackson_takehome1”) and include your name as part of the document front-/top-matter.
All take home projects are INDEPENDENT projects; do not share code or answers.
Note: In some instances I describe doing a question “by hand,” which means using the formulas to calculate the answers. This is contrasted with the simpler way of using R functions. It is recommended to use R functions if the “by hand” method is not explicitly stated; quicker & simpler is often preferred.
 Take home #1 Information will soon be given

title: Lectures

content:
People Instructor: Joshua Jackson
Office: Room #315B
Office hours: 10-11 Wednesday and by appointment
AI: Brent Rappaport
Office: Room 340A Office hours: Thursday 10:50-12:30
Super AI: Shelly Cooper
Office: Room 105

 Course Description This course will provide a detailed overview of multiple regression as a data-analytic method. The course provides a conceptual background of the central ideas and applications along with the necessary applied skills to carry out analyses of continuous and categorical data. The analytic approaches are thus applicable to experimental research in which factors are manipulated and to observational research. Goals are threefold: (1) learn how to look at and think about data – to check for problems in regression models, errors in computer outputs, identify missuses of regression, (2) be able to examine the relationship among regression models, theoretical models, and your data, and (3) construct regression equations to examine specific hypotheses and interpret resulting models and regression coefficients.

 Class textbook  Learning Statistics with R by Daniel Navarro http://www.compcogscisydney.com/learning-statistics-with-r.html  Recommended text (not required)
-Aiken, L. S., & West, S. G. (1991). Multiple regression: Testing and interpreting interactions. Newbury Park, CA: Sage Publications.
-Cohen, J., Cohen, P., West, S. G., & Aiken, L. A. (2003). Applied multiple regression/correlation analysis for the behavioral sciences (3rd edition). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.
-Cumming, G. (2013). Understanding the new statistics: Effect sizes, confidence intervals, and meta-analysis. Routledge.
-Myers, J.L., Well, A. D., & Lorch, R. F. (2010). Research Design & Statistical Analysis (3rd Ed.), New York, NY: Routledge.
-McElreath, R. (2016). Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in R. CRC Press.

 Grading The class consists of 2 in class tests, a cumulative final exam, 7 take home exams ie homeworks, and one oral “exam”. The 2 in class exams make up 40% of your grade (20% each). The final exam will account for 20%. The 7 take home projects fulfills 35% of your final grade (5% each) while the oral exam will make up the remaining 5%.
Typically, grades are “curved,” but not to a predefined distribution. The curve will always be in a manner that will help people, not hurt.
Due dates for exams and other project details will be listed on the announcements/home page. Expect exact dates to change throughout the semester so be sure to check the site frequently.
Note: take home homeworks should be treated like exams. No discussing of questions or sharing code. Any duplicate code will result in zero points for that section. In the past this has frustrated people. However, the necessary code is 1. mostly available in the lectures and 2. able to be found online with some simple searches. The struggle of not having your code immediately work is real and is experienced by everyone. This is normal and thus should be expected. Thus, please give yourself ample time to work on these takehome projects. Getting practice to search for and deal with code problems is a useful skill set to develop. If you are hitting your head against a wall for hours please ask Brent, Shelly or I for advice.
Grades:
100% - A+
99-92 - A
90-91 - A-
89 - B+
88-81 - B
80 - B-
79-70 - C
69-60 - D
<60 - F

 Schedule Note that dates and readings are tentative. Topics will likely shift; all changes will be updated on the homepage, not necessarily in the syllabus below.
  Week Date Topic LSR readings Additional Readings    1 1/14 Recap and GLM intro  Cumming’s new stat, if needed  - 1/16 GLM and Categorical predictors (re-read 13-14 for review)   2 1/21 Correlation  Correlation Revelle  - 1/23 Correlation    3 1/28 Univariate Regression 15.1-15.2   - 1/30 Univariate Regression  MR Cohen chapter  4 2/4 Partial Correlations 15.3- end of chapter   - 2/6 Multiple Regression    5 2/11 Multiple Regression    - 2/13 Multiple Regression    6 2/18 Multiple Regression    - 2/20 Exam 1    7 2/25 Assumptions, model diagnostics    - 2/27 Assumptions, model diagnostics    8 3/3 Moderation/interaction  Aiken Chapter  - 3/5 Moderation/interaction  Aiken Chapter  9 3/10 Spring Break!    - 3/12 Spring Break!    10 3/17 Polynomials    - 3/19 Factorial ANOVA Chapter 16   11 3/24 Factorial ANOVA  Myers chapter  - 3/26 Cont and cat predictors (ANCOVA)    12 3/31 Logistic regression/GLM  Cohen Logistic Chapter  - 4/2 Over/underfitting and validation  Yarkoni Westfall paper  13 4/7 Repeated measures/MLM  Hoffman BRM  - 4/9 Repeated measures/MLM    14 4/14 Repeated measures/MLM    - 4/16 Exam 2    15 4/21 Bayesian statistics Chapter 17 Kruschke PBR  - 4/23 Bayesian regression    - 5/5 Final Exam TIME TBA
